      85                 :            :  *  rate (by our own policy, see INVENTORY_BROADCAST_PER_SECOND) for several minutes, while not receiving

      97                 :            : static const unsigned int MAX_GETDATA_SZ = 1000;

     102                 :            : /** Number of headers sent in one getheaders result. We rely on the assumption that if a peer sends
     103                 :            :  *  less than this number, we reached its tip. Changing this value is a protocol upgrade. */
     104                 :            : static const unsigned int MAX_HEADERS_RESULTS = 2000;

     106                 :            :  *  when requested. For older blocks, a regular BLOCK response will be sent. */
     107                 :            : static const int MAX_CMPCTBLOCK_DEPTH = 5;

     109                 :            : static const int MAX_BLOCKTXN_DEPTH = 10;
     110                 :            : /** Size of the "block download window": how far ahead of our current height do we fetch?
     111                 :            :  *  Larger windows tolerate larger download speed differences between peer, but increase the potential
     112                 :            :  *  degree of disordering of blocks on disk (which make reindexing and pruning harder). We'll probably
     113                 :            :  *  want to make this a per-peer adaptive value at some point. */
     114                 :            : static const unsigned int BLOCK_DOWNLOAD_WINDOW = 1024;

     178                 :            : /**
     179                 :            :  * Data structure for an individual peer. This struct is not protected by
     180                 :            :  * cs_main since it does not contain validation-critical data.
     181                 :            :  *
     182                 :            :  * Memory is owned by shared pointers and this object is destructed when
     183                 :            :  * the refcount drops to zero.
     184                 :            :  *
     185                 :            :  * Mutexes inside this struct must not be held when locking m_peer_mutex.

     187                 :            :  * TODO: move most members from CNodeState to this structure.

     235                 :            :      *

     238                 :            :     std::unique_ptr<CRollingBloomFilter> m_addr_known;
     239                 :            :     /** Whether we are participating in address relay with this connection.
     240                 :            :      *
     241                 :            :      *  We set this bool to true for outbound peers (other than
     242                 :            :      *  block-relay-only connections), or when an inbound peer sends us an
     243                 :            :      *  address related message (ADDR, ADDRV2, GETADDR).
     244                 :            :      *
     245                 :            :      *  We use this bool to decide whether a peer is eligible for gossiping
     246                 :            :      *  addr messages. This avoids relaying to peers that are unlikely to
     247                 :            :      *  forward them, effectively blackholing self announcements. Reasons
     248                 :            :      *  peers might support addr relay on the link include that they connected
     249                 :            :      *  to us as a block-relay-only peer or they are a light client.
     250                 :            :      *
     251                 :            :      *  This field must correlate with whether m_addr_known has been
     252                 :            :      *  initialized.*/
     253                 :            :     std::atomic_bool m_addr_relay_enabled{false};

     345                 :            :     /**
     346                 :            :      * Potentially mark a node discouraged based on the contents of a BlockValidationState object
     347                 :            :      *
     348                 :            :      * @param[in] via_compact_block this bool is passed in because net_processing should
     349                 :            :      * punish peers differently depending on whether the data was provided in a compact
     350                 :            :      * block message or not. If the compact block had a valid header, but contained invalid
     351                 :            :      * txs, the peer should not be punished. See BIP 152.
     352                 :            :      *
     353                 :            :      * @return Returns true if the peer was punished (probably disconnected)
     354                 :            :      */
     355                 :            :     bool MaybePunishNodeForBlock(NodeId nodeid, const BlockValidationState& state,
     356                 :            :                                  bool via_compact_block, const std::string& message = "");
     357                 :            : 
     358                 :            :     /**

     430                 :            :       * on extra block-relay-only peers. */
     431                 :            :     bool m_initial_sync_finished{false};
     432                 :            : 
     433                 :            :     /** Protects m_peer_map. This mutex must not be locked while holding a lock
     434                 :            :      *  on any of the mutexes inside a Peer object. */
     435                 :            :     mutable Mutex m_peer_mutex;
     436                 :            :     /**
     437                 :            :      * Map of all Peer objects, keyed by peer id. This map is protected
     438                 :            :      * by the m_peer_mutex. Once a shared pointer reference is
     439                 :            :      * taken, the lock may be released. Individual fields are protected by
     440                 :            :      * their own locks.
     441                 :            :      */
     442                 :            :     std::map<NodeId, PeerRef> m_peer_map GUARDED_BY(m_peer_mutex);
     443                 :            : 
     444                 :            :     /** Number of nodes with fSyncStarted. */
     445                 :            :     int nSyncStarted GUARDED_BY(cs_main) = 0;
     446                 :            : 
     447                 :            :     /**
     448                 :            :      * Sources of received blocks, saved to be able punish them when processing
     449                 :            :      * happens afterwards.
     450                 :            :      * Set mapBlockSource[hash].second to false if the node should not be
     451                 :            :      * punished if the block is invalid.
     452                 :            :      */
     453                 :            :     std::map<uint256, std::pair<NodeId, bool>> mapBlockSource GUARDED_BY(cs_main);
     454                 :            : 
     455                 :            :     /** Number of peers with wtxid relay. */
     456                 :            :     int m_wtxid_relay_peers GUARDED_BY(cs_main) = 0;
     457                 :            : 
     458                 :            :     /** Number of outbound peers with m_chain_sync.m_protect. */
     459                 :            :     int m_outbound_peers_with_protect_from_disconnect GUARDED_BY(cs_main) = 0;
     460                 :            : 
     461                 :            :     bool AlreadyHaveTx(const GenTxid& gtxid) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
     462                 :            : 
     463                 :            :     /**
     464                 :            :      * Filter for transactions that were recently rejected by the mempool.
     465                 :            :      * These are not rerequested until the chain tip changes, at which point
     466                 :            :      * the entire filter is reset.
     467                 :            :      *
     468                 :            :      * Without this filter we'd be re-requesting txs from each of our peers,
     469                 :            :      * increasing bandwidth consumption considerably. For instance, with 100
     470                 :            :      * peers, half of which relay a tx we don't accept, that might be a 50x
     471                 :            :      * bandwidth increase. A flooding attacker attempting to roll-over the
     472                 :            :      * filter using minimum-sized, 60byte, transactions might manage to send
     473                 :            :      * 1000/sec if we have fast peers, so we pick 120,000 to give our peers a
     474                 :            :      * two minute window to send invs to us.
     475                 :            :      *
     476                 :            :      * Decreasing the false positive rate is fairly cheap, so we pick one in a
     477                 :            :      * million to make it highly unlikely for users to have issues with this
     478                 :            :      * filter.
     479                 :            :      *
     480                 :            :      * We typically only add wtxids to this filter. For non-segwit
     481                 :            :      * transactions, the txid == wtxid, so this only prevents us from
     482                 :            :      * re-downloading non-segwit transactions when communicating with
     483                 :            :      * non-wtxidrelay peers -- which is important for avoiding malleation
     484                 :            :      * attacks that could otherwise interfere with transaction relay from
     485                 :            :      * non-wtxidrelay peers. For communicating with wtxidrelay peers, having
     486                 :            :      * the reject filter store wtxids is exactly what we want to avoid
     487                 :            :      * redownload of a rejected transaction.
     488                 :            :      *
     489                 :            :      * In cases where we can tell that a segwit transaction will fail
     490                 :            :      * validation no matter the witness, we may add the txid of such
     491                 :            :      * transaction to the filter as well. This can be helpful when
     492                 :            :      * communicating with txid-relay peers or if we were to otherwise fetch a
     493                 :            :      * transaction via txid (eg in our orphan handling).
     494                 :            :      *
     495                 :            :      * Memory used: 1.3 MB
     496                 :            :      */
     497                 :            :     CRollingBloomFilter m_recent_rejects GUARDED_BY(::cs_main){120'000, 0.000'001};
     498                 :            :     uint256 hashRecentRejectsChainTip GUARDED_BY(cs_main);
     499                 :            : 
     500                 :            :     /*
     501                 :            :      * Filter for transactions that have been recently confirmed.
     502                 :            :      * We use this to avoid requesting transactions that have already been
     503                 :            :      * confirnmed.
     504                 :            :      *
     505                 :            :      * Blocks don't typically have more than 4000 transactions, so this should
     506                 :            :      * be at least six blocks (~1 hr) worth of transactions that we can store,
     507                 :            :      * inserting both a txid and wtxid for every observed transaction.
     508                 :            :      * If the number of transactions appearing in a block goes up, or if we are
     509                 :            :      * seeing getdata requests more than an hour after initial announcement, we
     510                 :            :      * can increase this number.
     511                 :            :      * The false positive rate of 1/1M should come out to less than 1
     512                 :            :      * transaction per day that would be inadvertently ignored (which is the
     513                 :            :      * same probability that we have in the reject filter).
     514                 :            :      */
     515                 :            :     Mutex m_recent_confirmed_transactions_mutex;
     516                 :            :     CRollingBloomFilter m_recent_confirmed_transactions GUARDED_BY(m_recent_confirmed_transactions_mutex){48'000, 0.000'001};
     517                 :            : 
     518                 :            :     /** Have we requested this block from a peer */
     519                 :            :     bool IsBlockRequested(const uint256& hash) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
     520                 :            : 
     521                 :            :     /** Remove this block from our tracked requested blocks. Called if:
     522                 :            :      *  - the block has been received from a peer
     523                 :            :      *  - the request for the block has timed out
     524                 :            :      */
     525                 :            :     void RemoveBlockRequest(const uint256& hash) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
     526                 :            : 
     527                 :            :     /* Mark a block as in flight
     528                 :            :      * Returns false, still setting pit, if the block was already in flight from the same peer
     529                 :            :      * pit will only be valid as long as the same cs_main lock is being held
     530                 :            :      */
     531                 :            :     bool BlockRequested(NodeId nodeid, const CBlockIndex& block, std::list<QueuedBlock>::iterator** pit = nullptr) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
     532                 :            : 
     533                 :            :     bool TipMayBeStale() EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
     534                 :            :

     539                 :            :

     543                 :            :     std::atomic<int64_t> m_last_tip_update{0};

     590                 :            : 
     591                 :            :     /**

     601                 :            :     /**

     658                 :            : };
     659                 :            : } // namespace
     660                 :            : 
     661                 :            : namespace {
     662                 :            :     /** Number of preferable block download peers. */
     663                 :            :     int nPreferredDownload GUARDED_BY(cs_main) = 0;
     664                 :            : } // namespace
     665                 :            : 
     666                 :            : namespace {
     667                 :            : /**
     668                 :            :  * Maintain validation-specific state about nodes, protected by cs_main, instead
     669                 :            :  * by CNode's own locks. This simplifies asynchronous operation, where
     670                 :            :  * processing of incoming data is done after the ProcessMessage call returns,
     671                 :            :  * and we're no longer holding the node's locks.
     672                 :            :  */
     673                 :       1120 : struct CNodeState {
     674                 :            :     //! The best known block we know this peer has announced.
     675                 :            :     const CBlockIndex* pindexBestKnownBlock{nullptr};
     676                 :            :     //! The hash of the last unknown block this peer has announced.
     677                 :            :     uint256 hashLastUnknownBlock{};
     678                 :            :     //! The last full block we both have.
     679                 :            :     const CBlockIndex* pindexLastCommonBlock{nullptr};
     680                 :            :     //! The best header we have sent our peer.
     681                 :            :     const CBlockIndex* pindexBestHeaderSent{nullptr};
     682                 :            :     //! Length of current-streak of unconnecting headers announcements
     683                 :            :     int nUnconnectingHeaders{0};
     684                 :            :     //! Whether we've started headers synchronization with this peer.
     685                 :            :     bool fSyncStarted{false};
     686                 :            :     //! When to potentially disconnect peer for stalling headers download
     687                 :            :     std::chrono::microseconds m_headers_sync_timeout{0us};
     688                 :            :     //! Since when we're stalling block download progress (in microseconds), or 0.
     689                 :            :     std::chrono::microseconds m_stalling_since{0us};
     690                 :            :     std::list<QueuedBlock> vBlocksInFlight;
     691                 :            :     //! When the first entry in vBlocksInFlight started downloading. Don't care when vBlocksInFlight is empty.
     692                 :            :     std::chrono::microseconds m_downloading_since{0us};
     693                 :            :     int nBlocksInFlight{0};
     694                 :            :     //! Whether we consider this a preferred download peer.
     695                 :            :     bool fPreferredDownload{false};
     696                 :            :     //! Whether this peer wants invs or headers (when possible) for block announcements.
     697                 :            :     bool fPreferHeaders{false};
     698                 :            :     //! Whether this peer wants invs or cmpctblocks (when possible) for block announcements.
     699                 :            :     bool fPreferHeaderAndIDs{false};
     700                 :            :     /**
     701                 :            :       * Whether this peer will send us cmpctblocks if we request them.
     702                 :            :       * This is not used to gate request logic, as we really only care about fSupportsDesiredCmpctVersion,
     703                 :            :       * but is used as a flag to "lock in" the version of compact blocks (fWantsCmpctWitness) we send.
     704                 :            :       */
     705                 :            :     bool fProvidesHeaderAndIDs{false};
     706                 :            :     //! Whether this peer can give us witnesses
     707                 :            :     bool fHaveWitness{false};
     708                 :            :     //! Whether this peer wants witnesses in cmpctblocks/blocktxns
     709                 :            :     bool fWantsCmpctWitness{false};
     710                 :            :     /**
     711                 :            :      * If we've announced NODE_WITNESS to this peer: whether the peer sends witnesses in cmpctblocks/blocktxns,
     712                 :            :      * otherwise: whether this peer sends non-witnesses in cmpctblocks/blocktxns.
     713                 :            :      */
     714                 :            :     bool fSupportsDesiredCmpctVersion{false};
     715                 :            : 
     716                 :            :     /** State used to enforce CHAIN_SYNC_TIMEOUT and EXTRA_PEER_CHECK_INTERVAL logic.
     717                 :            :       *
     718                 :            :       * Both are only in effect for outbound, non-manual, non-protected connections.
     719                 :            :       * Any peer protected (m_protect = true) is not chosen for eviction. A peer is
     720                 :            :       * marked as protected if all of these are true:
     721                 :            :       *   - its connection type is IsBlockOnlyConn() == false
     722                 :            :       *   - it gave us a valid connecting header
     723                 :            :       *   - we haven't reached MAX_OUTBOUND_PEERS_TO_PROTECT_FROM_DISCONNECT yet
     724                 :            :       *   - its chain tip has at least as much work as ours
     725                 :            :       *
     726                 :            :       * CHAIN_SYNC_TIMEOUT: if a peer's best known block has less work than our tip,
     727                 :            :       * set a timeout CHAIN_SYNC_TIMEOUT seconds in the future:
     728                 :            :       *   - If at timeout their best known block now has more work than our tip
     729                 :            :       *     when the timeout was set, then either reset the timeout or clear it
     730                 :            :       *     (after comparing against our current tip's work)
     731                 :            :       *   - If at timeout their best known block still has less work than our
     732                 :            :       *     tip did when the timeout was set, then send a getheaders message,
     733                 :            :       *     and set a shorter timeout, HEADERS_RESPONSE_TIME seconds in future.
     734                 :            :       *     If their best known block is still behind when that new timeout is
     735                 :            :       *     reached, disconnect.
     736                 :            :       *
     737                 :            :       * EXTRA_PEER_CHECK_INTERVAL: after each interval, if we have too many outbound peers,
     738                 :            :       * drop the outbound one that least recently announced us a new block.
     739                 :            :       */
     740         [ +  - ]:       1120 :     struct ChainSyncTimeoutState {

    1092                 :       1111 : void PeerManagerImpl::PushNodeVersion(CNode& pnode, int64_t nTime)
    1093                 :            : {
    1094                 :            :     // Note that pnode->GetLocalServices() is a reflection of the local

    1290                 :            :     // due to a new block arriving or other large transfer.
    1291                 :            :     // Merely reporting pingtime might fool the caller into thinking the node was still responsive,
    1292                 :            :     // since pingtime does not update until the ping is complete, which might take a while.

    1450                 :        717 : void PeerManagerImpl::StartScheduledTasks(CScheduler& scheduler)
    1451                 :            : {
    1452                 :            :     // Stale tip checking and peer eviction are on two different timers, but we
    1453                 :            :     // don't want them to get out of sync due to drift in the scheduler, so we
    1454                 :            :     // combine them in one function and schedule at the quicker (peer-eviction)
    1455                 :            :     // timer.

    1492                 :       4677 : void PeerManagerImpl::BlockDisconnected(const std::shared_ptr<const CBlock> &block, const CBlockIndex* pindex)
    1493                 :            : {
    1494                 :            :     // To avoid relay problems with transactions that were previously
    1495                 :            :     // confirmed, clear our filter of recently confirmed transactions whenever
    1496                 :            :     // there's a reorg.
    1497                 :            :     // This means that in a 1-block reorg (where 1 block is disconnected and
    1498                 :            :     // then another block reconnected), our filter will drop to having only one
    1499                 :            :     // block's worth of transactions in it, but that should be fine, since
    1500                 :            :     // presumably the most common case of relaying a confirmed transaction
    1501                 :            :     // should be just after a new block containing it is found.
    1502                 :       4677 :     LOCK(m_recent_confirmed_transactions_mutex);

    1695                 :         33 : void PeerManagerImpl::RelayAddress(NodeId originator,
    1696                 :            :                                    const CAddress& addr,
    1697                 :            :                                    bool fReachable)
    1698                 :            : {
    1699                 :            :     // We choose the same nodes within a given 24h window (if the list of connected
    1700                 :            :     // nodes does not change) and we don't relay to nodes that already know an
    1701                 :            :     // address. So within 24h we will likely relay a given address once. This is to
    1702                 :            :     // prevent a peer from unjustly giving their address better propagation by sending
    1703                 :            :     // it to us repeatedly.
    1704                 :            : 
    1705   [ +  +  +  - ]:         33 :     if (!fReachable && !addr.IsRelayable()) return;
    1706                 :            : 
    1707                 :            :     // Relay to a limited number of other nodes
    1708                 :            :     // Use deterministic randomness to send to the same nodes for 24 hours
    1709                 :            :     // at a time so the m_addr_knowns of the chosen nodes prevent repeats
    1710                 :         33 :     uint64_t hashAddr = addr.GetHash();
    1711                 :         33 :     const CSipHasher hasher = m_connman.GetDeterministicRandomizer(RANDOMIZER_ID_ADDRESS_RELAY).Write(hashAddr << 32).Write((GetTime() + hashAddr) / (24 * 60 * 60));
    1712                 :         33 :     FastRandomContext insecure_rand;
    1713                 :            : 
    1714                 :            :     // Relay reachable addresses to 2 peers. Unreachable addresses are relayed randomly to 1 or 2 peers.
    1715   [ +  +  +  - ]:         33 :     unsigned int nRelayNodes = (fReachable || (hasher.Finalize() & 1)) ? 2 : 1;
    1716                 :            : 
    1717                 :         33 :     std::array<std::pair<uint64_t, Peer*>, 2> best{{{0, nullptr}, {0, nullptr}}};
    1718         [ -  + ]:         33 :     assert(nRelayNodes <= best.size());
    1719                 :            : 
    1720                 :         66 :     LOCK(m_peer_mutex);
    1721                 :            : 
    1722   [ +  +  +  + ]:        162 :     for (auto& [id, peer] : m_peer_map) {
    1723   [ +  +  +  +  :        129 :         if (peer->m_addr_relay_enabled && id != originator && IsAddrCompatible(*peer, addr)) {
             +  -  +  - ]
    1724   [ +  -  +  - ]:         92 :             uint64_t hashKey = CSipHasher(hasher).Write(id).Finalize();
    1725         [ +  + ]:        156 :             for (unsigned int i = 0; i < nRelayNodes; i++) {
    1726         [ +  + ]:        131 :                  if (hashKey > best[i].first) {
    1727                 :         67 :                      std::copy(best.begin() + i, best.begin() + nRelayNodes - 1, best.begin() + i + 1);

    1997                 :            :         // SPV clients care about this message: it's needed when they are
    1998                 :            :         // recursively walking the dependencies of relevant unconfirmed
    1999                 :            :         // transactions. SPV clients want to do that because they want to know
    2000                 :            :         // about (and store and rebroadcast and risk analyze) the dependencies
    2001                 :            :         // of transactions relevant to them, without having to download the
    2002                 :            :         // entire memory pool.

    2060                 :            :         //   don't connect before giving DoS points

    2226                 :            : /**

    2272                 :            :                 // Do not add txids of witness transactions or witness-stripped
    2273                 :            :                 // transactions to the filter, as they can have been malleated;
    2274                 :            :                 // adding such txids to the reject filter would potentially
    2275                 :            :                 // interfere with relay of valid transactions from peers that
    2276                 :            :                 // do not support wtxid-based relay. See
    2277                 :            :                 // https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/8279 for details.

    2279                 :            :                 // the filter even for witness stripped transactions) once
    2280                 :            :                 // wtxid-based relay is broadly deployed.
    2281                 :            :                 // See also comments in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/18044#discussion_r443419034

    2288                 :            :                 // (the scriptPubKey being spent is covered by the txid).
    2289                 :            :                 // Add the txid to the reject filter to prevent repeated
    2290                 :            :                 // processing of this transaction in the event that child

    3349         [ +  - ]:          3 :                 m_txrequest.ForgetTxHash(tx.GetHash());
    3350         [ +  - ]:          3 :                 m_txrequest.ForgetTxHash(tx.GetWitnessHash());
    3351                 :            :             }
    3352                 :            :         } else {
    3353         [ +  + ]:        139 :             if (state.GetResult() != TxValidationResult::TX_WITNESS_STRIPPED) {
    3354                 :            :                 // We can add the wtxid of this transaction to our reject filter.
    3355                 :            :                 // Do not add txids of witness transactions or witness-stripped
    3356                 :            :                 // transactions to the filter, as they can have been malleated;
    3357                 :            :                 // adding such txids to the reject filter would potentially
    3358                 :            :                 // interfere with relay of valid transactions from peers that
    3359                 :            :                 // do not support wtxid-based relay. See
    3360                 :            :                 // https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/8279 for details.
    3361                 :            :                 // We can remove this restriction (and always add wtxids to
    3362                 :            :                 // the filter even for witness stripped transactions) once
    3363                 :            :                 // wtxid-based relay is broadly deployed.
    3364                 :            :                 // See also comments in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/18044#discussion_r443419034
    3365                 :            :                 // for concerns around weakening security of unupgraded nodes
    3366                 :            :                 // if we start doing this too early.
    3367         [ +  - ]:        138 :                 m_recent_rejects.insert(tx.GetWitnessHash());
    3368         [ +  - ]:        138 :                 m_txrequest.ForgetTxHash(tx.GetWitnessHash());
    3369                 :            :                 // If the transaction failed for TX_INPUTS_NOT_STANDARD,
    3370                 :            :                 // then we know that the witness was irrelevant to the policy
    3371                 :            :                 // failure, since this check depends only on the txid
    3372                 :            :                 // (the scriptPubKey being spent is covered by the txid).
    3373                 :            :                 // Add the txid to the reject filter to prevent repeated
    3374                 :            :                 // processing of this transaction in the event that child
    3375                 :            :                 // transactions are later received (resulting in
    3376                 :            :                 // parent-fetching by txid via the orphan-handling logic).
    3377   [ +  +  +  + ]:        138 :                 if (state.GetResult() == TxValidationResult::TX_INPUTS_NOT_STANDARD && tx.GetWitnessHash() != tx.GetHash()) {
    3378         [ +  - ]:          1 :                     m_recent_rejects.insert(tx.GetHash());
    3379         [ +  - ]:          1 :                     m_txrequest.ForgetTxHash(tx.GetHash());
    3380                 :            :                 }
    3381         [ +  + ]:        138 :                 if (RecursiveDynamicUsage(*ptx) < 100000) {
    3382         [ +  - ]:        137 :                     AddToCompactExtraTransactions(ptx);
    3383                 :            :                 }
    3384                 :            :             }
    3385                 :            :         }
    3386                 :            : 
    3387                 :            :         // If a tx has been detected by m_recent_rejects, we will have reached
    3388                 :            :         // this point and the tx will have been ignored. Because we haven't
    3389                 :            :         // submitted the tx to our mempool, we won't have computed a DoS
    3390                 :            :         // score for it or determined exactly why we consider it invalid.
    3391                 :            :         //
    3392                 :            :         // This means we won't penalize any peer subsequently relaying a DoSy
    3393                 :            :         // tx (even if we penalized the first peer who gave it to us) because
    3394                 :            :         // we have to account for m_recent_rejects showing false positives. In
    3395                 :            :         // other words, we shouldn't penalize a peer if we aren't *sure* they
    3396                 :            :         // submitted a DoSy tx.
    3397                 :            :         //
    3398                 :            :         // Note that m_recent_rejects doesn't just record DoSy or invalid
    3399                 :            :         // transactions, but any tx not accepted by the mempool, which may be
    3400                 :            :         // due to node policy (vs. consensus). So we can't blanket penalize a
    3401                 :            :         // peer simply for relaying a tx that our m_recent_rejects has caught,
    3402                 :            :         // regardless of false positives.
    3403                 :            : 
    3404         [ +  + ]:       9969 :         if (state.IsInvalid()) {

    3662   [ +  -  +  -  :          2 :                 m_connman.PushMessage(&pfrom, msgMaker.Make(NetMsgType::GETDATA, invs));
                   +  - ]
    3663                 :            :             } else {
    3664                 :            :                 // Block is either okay, or possibly we received
    3665                 :            :                 // READ_STATUS_CHECKBLOCK_FAILED.
    3666                 :            :                 // Note that CheckBlock can only fail for one of a few reasons:
    3667                 :            :                 // 1. bad-proof-of-work (impossible here, because we've already
    3668                 :            :                 //    accepted the header)
    3669                 :            :                 // 2. merkleroot doesn't match the transactions given (already
    3670                 :            :                 //    caught in FillBlock with READ_STATUS_FAILED, so
    3671                 :            :                 //    impossible here)
    3672                 :            :                 // 3. the block is otherwise invalid (eg invalid coinbase,
    3673                 :            :                 //    block is too big, too many legacy sigops, etc).
    3674                 :            :                 // So if CheckBlock failed, #3 is the only possibility.
    3675                 :            :                 // Under BIP 152, we don't discourage the peer unless proof of work is
    3676                 :            :                 // invalid (we don't require all the stateless checks to have
    3677                 :            :                 // been run).  This is handled below, so just treat this as
    3678                 :            :                 // though the block was successfully read, and rely on the
    3679                 :            :                 // handling in ProcessNewBlock to ensure the block index is
    3680                 :            :                 // updated, etc.
    3681         [ +  - ]:      18305 :                 RemoveBlockRequest(resp.blockhash); // it is now an empty pointer
    3682                 :      18305 :                 fBlockRead = true;
    3683                 :            :                 // mapBlockSource is used for potentially punishing peers and
    3684                 :            :                 // updating which peers send us compact blocks, so the race
    3685                 :            :                 // between here and cs_main in ProcessNewBlock is fine.
    3686                 :            :                 // BIP 152 permits peers to relay compact blocks after validating
    3687                 :            :                 // the header only; we should not punish peers if the block turns
    3688                 :            :                 // out to be invalid.
    3689   [ +  -  +  - ]:      36611 :                 mapBlockSource.emplace(resp.blockhash, std::make_pair(pfrom.GetId(), false));
    3690                 :            :             }
    3691                 :            :         } // Don't hold cs_main when we call into ProcessNewBlock
    3692         [ +  + ]:      18306 :         if (fBlockRead) {
    3693                 :            :             // Since we requested this block (it was in mapBlocksInFlight), force it to be processed,
    3694                 :            :             // even if it would not be a candidate for new tip (missing previous block, chain not long enough, etc)
    3695                 :            :             // This bypasses some anti-DoS logic in AcceptBlock (eg to prevent
    3696                 :            :             // disk-space attacks), but this should be safe due to the

    3698                 :            :             // in compact block optimistic reconstruction handling.

    3824         [ +  + ]:       5195 :     if (msg_type == NetMsgType::PING) {
    3825         [ +  - ]:       3009 :         if (pfrom.GetCommonVersion() > BIP0031_VERSION) {
    3826                 :       3009 :             uint64_t nonce = 0;
    3827         [ +  - ]:       3009 :             vRecv >> nonce;
    3828                 :            :             // Echo the message back with the nonce. This allows for two useful features:
    3829                 :            :             //
    3830                 :            :             // 1) A remote node can quickly check if the connection is operational
    3831                 :            :             // 2) Remote nodes can measure the latency of the network thread. If this node
    3832                 :            :             //    is overloaded it won't respond to pings quickly and the remote node can
    3833                 :            :             //    avoid sending us more work, like chain download requests.
    3834                 :            :             //
    3835                 :            :             // The nonce stops the remote getting confused between different pings: without
    3836                 :            :             // it, if the remote node sends a ping once per second and this node takes 5
    3837                 :            :             // seconds to respond to each, the 5th ping the remote sends would appear to
    3838                 :            :             // return very quickly.
    3839   [ +  -  +  -  :       9027 :             m_connman.PushMessage(&pfrom, msgMaker.Make(NetMsgType::PONG, nonce));
                   +  - ]
    3840                 :            :         }

    4191                 :         46 : void PeerManagerImpl::EvictExtraOutboundPeers(int64_t time_in_seconds)
    4192                 :            : {
    4193                 :            :     // If we have any extra block-relay-only peers, disconnect the youngest unless
    4194                 :            :     // it's given us a block -- in which case, compare with the second-youngest, and
    4195                 :            :     // out of those two, disconnect the peer who least recently gave us a block.
    4196                 :            :     // The youngest block-relay-only peer would be the extra peer we connected

    4869                 :            :             // the download window should be much larger than the to-be-downloaded set of blocks, so disconnection
    4870                 :            :             // should only happen during initial block download.
    4871   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :             LogPrintf("Peer=%d is stalling block download, disconnecting\n", pto->GetId());

    4873         [ #  # ]:          0 :             return true;
    4874                 :            :         }
    4875                 :            :         // In case there is a block that has been in flight from this peer for block_interval * (1 + 0.5 * N)
    4876                 :            :         // (with N the number of peers from which we're downloading validated blocks), disconnect due to timeout.
    4877                 :            :         // We compensate for other peers to prevent killing off peers due to our own downstream link
    4878                 :            :         // being saturated. We only count validated in-flight blocks so peers can't advertise non-existing block hashes
    4879                 :            :         // to unreasonably increase our timeout.
